title: 111_hr2076
content: The "Border Security and Responsibility Act 2009" aims to protect Federal lands along the US-Mexico border from unauthorized immigration, smuggling, and border enforcement activities. It defines the purpose of the Act as ensuring the highest level of security while undertaking necessary operations. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "Indian tribe" and "Secretary" for the Act. SEC. 4. BORDER PROTECTION STRATEGY. This section outlines the border protection strategy to be implemented. The Border Protection Strategy requires multiple Secretaries to develop and submit a comprehensive plan for the international land borders of the United States by September 30, 2009, in consultation with tribal, State, and local officials. The strategy must include a comparative analysis of operational control levels achievable through various security measures. The Border Protection Strategy requires a comprehensive plan for international land borders by September 30, 2009, including pedestrian fencing, vehicle barriers, additional Border Patrol agents, natural barriers, and advanced technology for surveillance and response. The Border Protection Strategy aims to enhance border security through various measures such as regional variations in methodologies, cooperation with Mexico and Canada, and removal of obstructive vegetation. The comprehensive analysis of cost and impacts of security measures includes land acquisition, construction, maintenance, contractor, management, and overhead costs, as well as impacts on wildlife, habitat, natural communities, and cross-border wildlife migration corridors and hydrology. The comprehensive analysis includes costs and impacts of security measures on Federal, tribal, State, local, and private lands, waters, wildlife, and habitats, including the replacement or restoration of wildlife migration corridors. The curr_chunk discusses the consultation with tribal, State, and local governments, as well as authorities of Mexico and Canada, regarding the impacts on culture, safety, and quality of life near the border. It also includes a compilation of fiscal investments in acquiring or managing lands for conservation purposes along the U.S. borders. The curr_chunk outlines the designation of wildlife migration corridors in various jurisdictions including National Park System units, National Forest System land, Bureau of Land Management land, United States Fish and Wildlife Service land, Department of the Interior or Agriculture land, Department of Defense or individual military department land, Department of Commerce land, and tribal lands. The Department of Commerce, tribal lands, State and private lands, and lands within Mexico and Canada are included in the designation of wildlife migration corridors. Recommendations for strategic border security management are based on comparative security, cost-benefit analysis, and protection of investments in public lands. Required training includes natural resource protection training for Customs and Border Protection agents or other Federal personnel. The Secretary shall provide training for Customs and Border Protection agents and other Federal personnel involved in border security infrastructure and patrol duties, including cultural resource training and coordination with other agencies. The Secretary will coordinate with relevant agencies and tribal governments to ensure training for border security focuses on achieving objectives while minimizing adverse impacts on natural and cultural resources. SEC. 5. ACTIONS TO GAIN OPERATIONAL CONTROL OF THE INTERNATIONAL LAND BORDERS OF THE UNITED STATES. Amendment to improve operational control of the border. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to gain operational control of the international land borders of the United States, following the border protection strategy developed under the Border Security and Responsibility Act of 2009. Priority should be given to using remote cameras, sensors, natural barriers, manpower, unmanned aerial vehicles, and other low impact border enforcement techniques. Consultation with the Secretaries of Interior, Agriculture, and other relevant parties is necessary. The Secretary of Homeland Security must work with various government entities and private property owners to minimize the impact on the environment, culture, and safety near proposed action sites. This subsection does not create or negate any legal rights, affect eminent domain laws, or waive other applicable regulations. The Secretary of Homeland Security can waive other laws and is not required to install specific resources along the border if deemed ineffective or costly. The focus is on achieving and maintaining operational control while considering the impact on the environment, culture, and safety of border communities. The Secretary of Homeland Security must consider the negative impact on border communities before constructing any border infrastructure. Construction cannot begin until 90 days after submitting the required border protection strategy to Congress. SEC. 6. BORDERLANDS MONITORING AND MITIGATION. The Secretary, in consultation with various agencies, will develop a monitoring and mitigation plan to address environmental impacts of border security infrastructure along US international land borders. The plan will include measures to preserve wildlife migration corridors and key habitats. The Secretary will develop a monitoring and mitigation plan to address environmental impacts of border security infrastructure along US international land borders. The plan includes maintaining ecological connectivity between habitats, controlling invasive species, preserving hydrological functionality, implementing adaptive management, and protecting cultural and historical resources. The Secretary may carry out a mitigation plan on various lands near the US international border regardless of ownership. Activities must be done in consultation with the landowner. The Secretary of Homeland Security can transfer funds for this purpose. The Department of Homeland Security can transfer funds to other Federal agencies for conservation activities on non-Federal lands and mitigation activities on Federal lands. This transfer is exempt from reprogramming requirements. The Secretary of Homeland Security can accept donations for developing and implementing a mitigation plan, and transfer funds to other Federal agencies for expenditure under the plan. Appropriated funds for border security infrastructure can be used for the mitigation plan. These funds are exempt from reprogramming requirements.
